divert.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to change the use of something such as time or money
divert.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The company should divert more resources into research.
divert something into/to/(away) from etc something
Officials diverted revenue from arms sales to the rebels.
divert something into/to/(away) from etc something
divert.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to change the direction in which something travels
divert.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The high street is closed and traffic is being diverted.
Canals divert water from the Truckee River into the lake.
divert.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if you divert your telephone calls, you arrange for them to go directly to another number, for example because you are not able to answer them yourself for some time
divert.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Remember to divert your phone when you are out of the office.
divert.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to deliberately take someone’s attention from something by making them think about or notice other things
divert.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: He’d been trying to divert suspicion away from himself.
The crime crackdown is an attempt to divert attention from social problems.
divert.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to spend money or make an effort in a new area of business or a new product
divert.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The company should divert more resources into research.
